chapter.title: Chapter 10 Imaginary Journeys: The Lojban Space/Time Tense System

section.title: 1. Introductory
section.para:
This chapter attempts to document and explain the space/time tense system of Lojban. It does not attempt to answer all questions of the form
tense system How do I say such-and-such (an English tense) in Lojban?Instead, it explores the Lojban tense system from the inside, attempting to educate the reader into a Lojbanic viewpoint. Once the overall system is understood and the resources that it makes available are familiar, the reader should have some hope of using appropriate tense constructs and being correctly understood.

The system of Lojban tenses presented here may seem really complex because of all the pieces and all the options; indeed, this chapter is the longest one in this book. But tense is in fact complex in every language. In your native language, the subtleties of tense are intuitive. In foreign languages, you are seldom taught the entire system until you have reached an advanced level. Lojban tenses are extremely systematic and productive, allowing you to express subtleties based on what they mean rather than on how they act similarly to English tenses. This chapter concentrates on presenting an intuitive approach to the meaning of Lojban tense words and how they may be creatively and productively combined.

What is tense? Historically, tenseis the attribute of verbs in English and related languages that expresses the time of the action. In English, three tenses are traditionally recognized, conventionally called the past, the present, and the future. There are also a variety of compound tenses used in English. However, there is no simple relationship between the form of an English tense and the time actually expressed:
section.programlisting:
I go to London tomorrow.
tomorrow I will go to London tomorrow.
tomorrow I am going to London tomorrow.
tomorrow
section.para:
all mean the same thing, even though the first sentence uses the present tense; the second, the future tense; and the third, a compound tense usually called
tense in scope of sticky tense
multiple tenses compound tense present progressive. Likewise, a newspaper headline says JONES DIES, although it is obvious that the time referred to must be in the past. Tense is a mandatory category of English: every sentence must be marked for tense, even if in a way contrary to logic, because every main verb has a tense marker built into to it. By contrast, Lojban brivla have no implicit tense marker attached to them.

In Lojban, the concept of tense extends to every selbri, not merely the verb-like ones. In addition, tense structures provide information about location in space as well as in time. All tense information is optional in Lojban: a sentence like:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I go-to the market.

section.para: can be understood as:
section.programlisting: I went to the market. I am going to the market. I have gone to the market. I will go to the market. I continually go to the market.
section.para: as well as many other possibilities: context resolves which is correct.

The placement of a tense construct within a Lojban bridi is easy: right before the selbri. It goes immediately after the cu, and can in fact always replace the cu(although in very complex sentences the rules for eliding terminators may be changed as a result). In the following examples, puis the tense marker for past time:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi cu pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market.

section.para: It is also possible to put the tense somewhere else in the bridi by adding kuafter it. This kuis an elidable terminator, but it's almost never possible to actually elide it except at the end of the bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puku mi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: Earlier, I went to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama puku le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I went earlier to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu [ku]
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market earlier.

section.para: through are different only in emphasis. Abnormal order, such as through exhibit, adds emphasis to the words that have been moved; in this case, the tense cmavo pu. Words at either end of the sentence tend to be more noticeable.

section.title: 2. Spatial tenses: FAhA and VA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
(The complete list of FAhA cmavo can be found in .)

Why is this section about spatial tenses rather than the more familiar time tenses of
time tenses , asks the reader? Because the model to be used in explaining both will be easier to grasp for space than for time. The explanation of time tenses will resume in
time tenses
resume .

English doesn't have mandatory spatial tenses. Although there are plenty of ways in English of showing where an event happens, there is absolutely no need to do so. Considering this fact may give the reader a feel for what the optional Lojban time tenses are like. From the Lojban point of view, space and time are interchangeable, although they are not treated identically.

Lojban specifies the spatial tense of a bridi (the place at which it occurs) by using words from selma'o FAhA and VA to describe an imaginary journey from the speaker to the place referred to. FAhA cmavo specify the direction taken in the journey, whereas VA cmavo specify the distance gone. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu va batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [medium distance] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Over there the man is biting the dog.

section.para: What is at a medium distance? The event referred to by the bridi: the man biting the dog. What is this event at a medium distance from? The speaker's location. We can understand the vaas saying: If you want to get from the speaker's location to the location of the bridi, journey for a medium distance (in some direction unspecified).This imaginary journeycan be used to understand not only , but also every other spatial tense construct.
Suppose you specify a direction with a FAhA cmavo, rather than a distance with a VA cmavo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zu'a batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: The man [left] bites the dog.

section.para: Here the imaginary journey is again from the speaker's location to the location of the bridi, but it is now performed by going to the left (in the speaker's reference frame) for an unspecified distance. So a reasonable translation is:
section.programlisting: To my left, the man bites the dog.
section.para: The mydoes not have an explicit equivalent in the Lojban, because the speaker's location is understood as the starting point.

(Etymologically, by the way, zu'ais derived from zunle, the gismu for left, whereas vi, va, and vuare intended to be reminiscent of ti, ta, and tu, the demonstrative pronouns this-here, that-there, and that-yonder.)
What about specifying both a direction and a distance? The rule here is that the direction must come before the distance:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zu'avi batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [left] [short distance] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Slightly to my left, the man bites the dog.

section.para: As explained in , it would be perfectly correct to use kuto move this tense to the beginning or the end of the sentence to emphasize it:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: zu'aviku le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [Left] [short distance] the man bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Slightly to my left, the man bites the dog.

section.title: 3. Compound spatial tenses
section.para: Humph, says the reader: this talk of imaginary journeysis all very well, but what's the point of it? - zu'ameans on the leftand vimeans nearby, and there's no more to be said. The imaginary-journey model becomes more useful when so-called compound tenses are involved. A compound tense is exactly like a simple tense, but has several FAhAs run together:

indexterm.primary: tense in scope of sticky tense

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu ga'u zu'a batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: The man [up] [left] bites the dog.

section.para: The proper interpretation of is that the imaginary journey has two stages: first move from the speaker's location upward, and then to the left. A translation might read:
section.programlisting: Left of a place above me, the man bites the dog.
section.para: (Perhaps the speaker is at the bottom of a manhole, and the dog-biting is going on at the edge of the street.)

In the English translation, the keywords leftand aboveoccur in reverse order to the Lojban order. This effect is typical of what happens when we unfoldLojban compound tenses into their English equivalents, and shows why it is not very useful to try to memorize a list of Lojban tense constructs and their colloquial English equivalents.
The opposite order also makes sense:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zu'a ga'u batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: Above a place to the left of me, the man bites the dog.

section.para: In ordinary space, the result of going up and then to the left is the same as that of going left and then up, but such a simple relationship does not apply in all environments or to all directions: going south, then east, then north may return one to the starting point, if that point is the North Pole.
Each direction can have a distance following:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zu'avi ga'uvu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [left] [short distance] [up] [long distance] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Far above a place slightly to the left of me, the man bites the dog.

section.para: A distance can also come at the beginning of the tense construct, without any specified direction. ( , with VA alone, is really a special case of this rule when no directions at all follow.)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu vi zu'a batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [short distance] [left] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Left of a place near me, the man bites the dog.

section.para: Any number of directions may be used in a compound tense, with or without specified distances for each:

indexterm.primary: tense in scope of sticky tense

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu ca'uvi ni'ava ri'uvu ne'i
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Within a place a long distance to the right of a place which is a medium
distance downward from a place a short distance in front of me,
interlinear-gloss.en: the man bites the dog.

section.para: Whew! It's a good thing tense constructs are optional: having to say all that could certainly be painful. Note, however, how much shorter the Lojban version of is than the English version.

section.title: 4. Temporal tenses: PU and ZI
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

Now that the reader understands spatial tenses, there are only two main facts to understand about temporal tenses: they work exactly like the spatial tenses, with selma'o PU and ZI standing in for FAhA and VA; and when both spatial and temporal tense cmavo are given in a single tense construct, the temporal tense is expressed first. (If space could be expressed before or after time at will, then certain constructions would be ambiguous.)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu pu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bit the dog.

section.para: means that to reach the dog-biting, you must take an imaginary journey through time, moving towards the past an unspecified distance. (Of course, this journey is even more imaginary than the ones talked about in the previous sections, since time-travel is not an available option.)

Lojban recognizes three temporal directions: pufor the past, cafor the present, and bafor the future. (Etymologically, these derive from the corresponding gismu purci, cabna, and balvi. See for an explanation of the exact relationship between the cmavo and the gismu.) There are many more spatial directions, since there are FAhA cmavo for both absolute and relative directions as well as
spatial directions direction-like relationshipslike surrounding, within, touching, etc. (See for a complete list.) But there are really only two directions in time: forward and backward, toward the future and toward the past. Why, then, are there three cmavo of selma'o PU?

The reason is that tense is subjective: human beings perceive space and time in a way that does not necessarily agree with objective measurements. We have a sense of
measurements nowwhich includes part of the objective past and part of the objective future, and so we naturally segment the time line into three parts. The Lojban design recognizes this human reality by providing a separate time-direction cmavo for the zero direction, Similarly, there is a FAhA cmavo for the zero space direction: bu'u, which means something like
bu'u coinciding.

(Technical note for readers conversant with relativity theory: The Lojban time tenses reflect time as seen by the speaker, who is assumed to be a
time tenses
tense system relativity theory point-like observerin the relativistic sense: they do not say anything about physical relationships of relativistic interval, still less about implicit causality. The nature of tense is not only subjective but also observer-based.)
Here are some examples of temporal tenses:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu puzi batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [past] [short distance] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: A short time ago, the man bit the dog.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu pu pu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Earlier than an earlier time than now, the man bit the dog.
The man had bitten the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man had been biting the dog.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu ba puzi batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Shortly earlier than some time later than now, the man will bite the dog.
Soon before then, the man will have bitten the dog.
The man will have just bitten the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man will just have been biting the dog.

section.para: What about the analogue of an initial VA without a direction? Lojban does allow an initial ZI with or without following PUs:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zi pu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: Before a short time from or before now, the man bit or will bite the dog.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu zu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: A long time from or before now, the man will bite or bit the dog.

section.para: and are perfectly legitimate, but may not be very much used: ziby itself signals an event that happens at a time close to the present, but without saying whether it is in the past or the future. A rough translation might be about now, but not exactly now.

Because we can move in any direction in space, we are comfortable with the idea of events happening in an unspecified space direction ( nearbyor far away), but we live only from past to future, and the idea of an event which happens nearby in timeis a peculiar one. Lojban provides lots of such possibilities that don't seem all that useful to English-speakers, even though you can put them together productively; this fact may be a limitation of English.
Finally, here are examples which combine temporal and spatial tense:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu puzu vu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [past] [long time] [long space] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: Long ago and far away, the man bit the dog.

section.para: Alternatively,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu batci le gerku puzuvuku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog [past] [long time] [long space].
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bit the dog long ago and far away.

section.title: 5. Interval sizes: VEhA and ZEhA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

So far, we have considered only events that are usually thought of as happening at a particular point in space and time: a man biting a dog at a specified place and time. But Lojbanic events may be much more spread outthan that: mi vasxu(I breathe) is something which is true during the whole of my life from birth to death, and over the entire part of the earth where I spend my life. The cmavo of VEhA (for space) and ZEhA (for time) can be added to any of the tense constructs we have already studied to specify the size of the space or length of the time over which the bridi is claimed to be true.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ve'i cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [small space interval] walks-on the ice.
In a small space, the child walks on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walks about a small area of the ice.

section.para: means that her walking was done in a small area. Like the distances, the interval sizes are classified only roughly as small, medium, large, and are relative to the context: a small part of a room might be a large part of a table in that room.
Here is an example using a time interval:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ze'a cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [medium time interval] walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: For a medium time, the child walks/walked/will walk on the ice.

section.para: Note that with no time direction word, does not say when the walking happened: that would be determined by context. It is possible to specify both directions or distances and an interval, in which case the interval always comes afterward:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba pu ze'a cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [past] [medium time interval] walks-on the ice.
For a medium time, the child walked on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walked on the ice for a while.

section.para: In , the relationship of the interval to the specified point in time or space is indeterminate. Does the interval start at the point, end at the point, or is it centered on the point? By adding an additional direction cmavo after the interval, this question can be conclusively answered:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ca ze'ica cusku dei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [present] [short time interval – present] express this-utterance.
interlinear-gloss.en: I am now saying this sentence.

section.para: means that for an interval starting a short time in the past and extending to a short time in the future, I am expressing the utterance which is . Of course, shortis relative, as always in tenses. Even a long sentence takes up only a short part of a whole day; in a geological context, the era of Homo sapienswould only be a ze'iinterval.
By contrast,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ca ze'ipu cusku dei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [present] [short time interval – past] express this-utterance.
interlinear-gloss.en: I have just been saying this sentence.

section.para: means that for a short time interval extending from the past to the present I have been expressing . Here the imaginary journey starts at the present, lays down one end point of the interval, moves into the past, and lays down the other endpoint. Another example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu ze'aba citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [medium time interval - future] eat my meal.
For a medium time afterward, I ate my meal.
interlinear-gloss.en: I ate my meal for a while.

section.para: With cainstead of ba, becomes ,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu ze'aca citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [medium time interval – present] eat my meal.
For a medium time before and afterward, I ate my meal.
interlinear-gloss.en: I ate my meal for a while.

section.para: because the interval would then be centered on the past moment rather than oriented toward the future of that moment. The colloquial English translations are the same - English is not well-suited to representing this distinction.
Here are some examples of the use of space intervals with and without specified directions:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ri'u ve'i finpe
interlinear-gloss.en: That thing on my right is a fish.

section.para: In , there is no equivalent in the colloquial English translation of the small intervalwhich the fish occupies. Neither the Lojban nor the English expresses the orientation of the fish. Compare :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ri'u ve'ica'u finpe
interlinear-gloss.en: That thing on my right extending forwards is a fish.

section.para: Here the space interval occupied by the fish extends from a point on my right to another point in front of the first point.

section.title: 6. Vague intervals and non-specific tenses
section.para:
What is the significance of failing to specify an interval size of the type discussed in
interval size ? The Lojban rule is that if no interval size is given, the size of the space or time interval is left vague by the speaker. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I [past] go-to the market.

section.para: really means:
section.programlisting: At a moment in the past, and possibly other moments as well, the event I went to the market was in progress.
section.para: The vague or unspecified interval contains an instant in the speaker's past. However, there is no indication whether or not the whole interval is in the speaker's past! It is entirely possible that the interval during which the going-to-the-market is happening stretches into the speaker's present or even future.

points up a fundamental difference between Lojban tenses and English tenses. An English past-tense sentence like I went to the marketgenerally signifies that the going-to-the-market is entirely in the past; that is, that the event is complete at the time of speaking. Lojban puhas no such implication.
This property of a past tense is sometimes called aorist, in reference to a similar concept in the tense system of Classical Greek. All of the Lojban tenses have the same property, however:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le tricu ba crino
interlinear-gloss.en: The tree will be green.

section.para: does not imply (as the colloquial English translation does) that the tree is not green now. The vague interval throughout which the tree is, in fact, green may have already started.

This general principle does not mean that Lojban has no way of indicating that a tree will be green but is not yet green. Indeed, there are several ways of expressing that concept: see (event contours) and
tense direction event contours (logical connection between tenses).

section.title: 7. Dimensionality: VIhA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The cmavo of ZEhA are sufficient to express time intervals. One fundamental difference between space and time, however, is that space is multi-dimensional. Sometimes we want to say not only that something moves over a small interval, but also perhaps that it moves in a line. Lojban allows for this. I can specify that a motion in a small spaceis more specifically in a short line, in a small area, or through a small volume.

What about the child walking on the ice in through ? Given the nature of ice, probably the area interpretation is most sensible. I can make this assumption explicit with the appropriate member of selma'o VIhA:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ve'a vi'a cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [medium space interval] [2-dimensional] walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: In a medium-sized area, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: Space intervals can contain either VEhA or VIhA or both, but if both, VEhA must come first, as shows.

The reader may wish to raise a philosophical point here. (Readers who don't wish to, should skip this paragraph.) The ice may be two-dimensional, or more accurately its surface may be, but since the child is three-dimensional, her walking must also be. The subjective nature of Lojban tense comes to the rescue here: the action is essentially planar, and the third dimension of height is simply irrelevant to walking. Even walking on a mountain could be called
irrelevant
dimension vi'a, because relatively speaking the mountain is associated with an essentially two-dimensional surface. Motion which is not confined to such a surface (e.g., flying, or walking through a three-dimensional network of tunnels, or climbing among mountains rather than on a single mountain) would be properly described with
vi'a vi'u. So the cognitive, rather than the physical, dimensionality controls the choice of VIhA cmavo.

VIhA has a member vi'ewhich indicates a 4-dimensional interval, one that involves both space and time. This allows the spatial tenses to invade, to some degree, the temporal tenses; it is possible to make statements about space-time considered as an Einsteinian whole. (There are presently no cmavo of FAhA assigned to
vi'e
temporal tenses
Einsteinian pastwardand
pastward futurewardconsidered as space rather than time directions - they could be added, though, if Lojbanists find space-time expression useful.) If a temporal tense cmavo is used in the same tense construct with a
temporal tense
futureward vi'einterval, the resulting tense may be self-contradictory.

section.title: 8. Movement in space: MOhI
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

All the information carried by the tense constructs so far presented has been presumed to be static: the bridi is occurring somewhere or other in space and time, more or less remote from the speaker. Suppose the truth of the bridi itself depends on the result of a movement, or represents an action being done while the speaker is moving? This too can be represented by the tense system, using the cmavo
tense system mo'i(of selma'o MOhI) plus a spatial direction and optional distance; the direction now refers to a direction of motion rather than a static direction from the speaker.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba mo'i ri'u cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walks toward my right on the ice.

section.para: This is quite different from:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ri'u cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: To the right of me, the child walks on the ice.

section.para:
In either case, however, the reference frame for defining
reference frame rightand leftis the speaker's, not the child's. This can be changed thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba mo'i ri'u cadzu le bisli ma'i vo'a
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [movement] [right] walks on the ice in-reference-frame the-x1-place.
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walks toward her right on the ice.

section.para:
is analogous to . The cmavo ma'ibelongs to selma'o BAI (explained in
ma'i ), and allows specifying a reference frame.
Both a regular and a mo'i-flagged spatial tense can be combined, with the mo'iconstruct coming last:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba zu'avu mo'i ri'uvi cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: Far to the left of me, the child walks a short distance toward my right on the ice.

section.para: It is not grammatical to use multiple directions like zu'a ca'uafter mo'i, but complex movements can be expressed in a separate bridi.
Here is an example of a movement tense on a bridi not inherently involving movement:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi mo'i ca'uvu citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: While moving a long way forward, I eat my meal.

section.para: (Perhaps I am eating in an airplane.)
There is no parallel facility in Lojban at present for expressing movement in time - time travel - but one could be added easily if it ever becomes useful.

section.title: 9. Interval properties: TAhE and roi
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
section.programlisting:
di'i TAhE regularly
di'i na'o TAhE typically
na'o ru'i TAhE continuously
ru'i ta'e TAhE habitually
ta'e
di'inai TAhE irregularly na'onai TAhE atypically ru'inai TAhE intermittently
intermittently ta'enai TAhE contrary to habit
roi ROI
roi n times roinai ROI other than n times
ze'e ZEhA whole time interval
ze'e
whole time interval ve'e VEhA whole space interval
ve'e
section.para: Consider Lojban bridi which express events taking place in time. Whether a very short interval (a point) or a long interval of time is involved, the event may not be spread consistently throughout that interval. Lojban can use the cmavo of selma'o TAhE to express the idea of continuous or non-continuous actions.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puzu ze'u velckule
interlinear-gloss.en: Long ago I attended school for a long time.

section.para: probably does not mean that I attended school continuously throughout the whole of that long-ago interval. Actually, I attended school every day, except for school holidays. More explicitly,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puzu ze'u di'i velckule
interlinear-gloss.en: Long ago I regularly attended school for a long time.

section.para: Using TAhE does not require being so specific. Either the time direction or the time interval or both may be omitted (in which case they are vague). For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba ta'e klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I will habitually go to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I will make a habit of going to the market.

section.para: specifies the future, but the duration of the interval is indefinite. Similarly,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'o klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I typically go/went/will go to the market.

section.para: illustrates an interval property in isolation. There are no distance or direction cmavo, so the point of time is vague; likewise, there is no interval cmavo, so the length of the interval during which these goings-to-the-market take place is also vague. As always, context will determine these vague values.
Intermittentlyis the polar opposite notion to continuously, and is expressed not with its own cmavo, but by adding the negation suffix -nai(which belongs to selma'o NAI) to ru'i. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ru'inai cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: The child intermittently walks on the ice.

section.para: As shown in the cmavo table above, all the cmavo of TAhE may be negated with -nai; ru'inaiand di'inaiare probably the most useful.

An intermittent event can also be specified by counting the number of times during the interval that it takes place. The cmavo roi(which belongs to selma'o ROI) can be appended to a number to make a quantified tense. Quantified tenses are common in English, but not so commonly named: they are exemplified by the adverbs
roi
adverbs never, once, twice, thrice, ... always, and by the related phrases many times, a few times, too many times, and so on. All of these are handled in Lojban by a number plus -roi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market once.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi du'eroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market too often.

section.para: With the quantified tense alone, we don't know whether the past, the present, or the future is intended, but of course the quantified tense need not stand alone:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu reroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market twice.

section.para: The English is slightly over-specific here: it entails that both goings-to-the-market were in the past, which may or may not be true in the Lojban sentence, since the implied interval is vague. Therefore, the interval may start in the past but extend into the present or even the future.

Adding -naito roiis also permitted, and has the meaning
roi other than (the number specified):

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu reroinai citka le cirla
interlinear-gloss.en: The rat eats the cheese other than twice.

section.para: This may mean that the rat eats the cheese fewer times, or more times, or not at all.

It is necessary to be careful with sentences like and , where a quantified tense appears without an interval. What really says is that during an interval of unspecified size, at least part of which was set in the past, the event of my going to the market happened twice. The example says nothing about what happened outside that vague time interval. This is often less than we mean. If we want to nail down that I went to the market once and only once, we can use the cmavo
only once ze'ewhich represents the
ze'e whole time interval: conceptually, an interval which stretches from time's beginning to its end:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'e paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I [whole interval] [once] go-to the market.

section.para: Since specifying no ZEhA leaves the interval vague, might in appropriate context mean the same as after all - but allows us to be specific when specificity is necessary.

A PU cmavo following ze'ehas a slightly different meaning from one that follows another ZEhA cmavo. The compound cmavo
ze'e ze'epusignifies the interval stretching from the infinite past to the reference point (wherever the imaginary journey has taken you);
ze'epu ze'ebais the interval stretching from the reference point to the infinite future. The remaining form,
ze'eba ze'eca, makes specific the
ze'eca whole of timeinterpretation just given. These compound forms make it possible to assert that something has never happened without asserting that it never will.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'epu noroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I have never gone to the market.

section.para: says nothing about whether I might go in future.

The space equivalent of ze'eis
ze'e ve'e, and it can be used in the same way with a quantified space tense: see
ve'e
quantified space for an explanation of space interval modifiers.

section.title: 10. Event contours: ZAhO and re'u
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The cmavo of selma'o ZAhO express the Lojban version of what is traditionally called aspect. This is not a notion well expressed by English tenses, but many languages (including Chinese and Russian among Lojban's six source languages) consider it more important than the specification of mere position in time.

The event contoursof selma'o ZAhO, with their bizarre keywords, represent the natural portions of an event considered as a process, an occurrence with an internal structure including a beginning, a middle, and an end. Since the keywords are scarcely self-explanatory, each ZAhO will be explained in detail here. Note that from the viewpoint of Lojban syntax, ZAhOs are interval modifiers like TAhEs or ROI compounds; if both are found in a single tense, the TAhE/ROI comes first and the ZAhO afterward. The imaginary journey described by other tense cmavo moves us to the portion of the event-as-process which the ZAhO specifies.

It is important to understand that ZAhO cmavo, unlike the other tense cmavo, specify characteristic portions of the event, and are seen from an essentially timeless perspective. The beginningof an event is the same whether the event is in the speaker's present, past, or future. It is especially important not to confuse the speaker-relative viewpoint of the PU tenses with the event-relative viewpoint of the ZAhO tenses.
The cmavo pu'o, ca'o, and ba'o(etymologically derived from the PU cmavo) refer to an event that has not yet begun, that is in progress, or that has ended, respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu'o damba
interlinear-gloss.en: I'm on the verge of fighting.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la stiv. ca'o bacru
interlinear-gloss.en: Steve continues to talk.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ba'o cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: The child is finished walking on the ice.

section.para:
As discussed in , the simple PU cmavo make no assumptions about whether the scope of a past, present, or future event extends into one of the other tenses as well.
future event through illustrate that these ZAhO cmavo do make such assumptions possible: the event in 10.1 has not yet begun, definitively; likewise, the event in 10.3 is definitely over.

Note that in and , pu'oand ba'omay appear to be reversed: pu'o, although etymologically connected with pu, is referring to a future event; whereas
future event ba'o, connected with ba, is referring to a past event. This is the natural result of the event-centered view of ZAhO cmavo. The inchoative, or
past event pu'o, part of an event, is in the pastwardportion of that event, when seen from the perspective of the event itself. It is only by inference that we suppose that
pastward refers to the speaker's future: in fact, no PU tense is given, so the inchoative part of the event need not be coincident with the speaker's present: pu'ois not necessarily, though in fact often is, the same as ca pu'o.

The cmavo in through refer to spans of time. There are also two points of time that can be usefully associated with an event: the beginning, marked by co'a, and the end, marked by co'u. Specifically, co'amarks the boundary between the pu'oand ca'oparts of an event, and co'umarks the boundary between the ca'oand ba'oparts:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba co'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: I will begin to eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu co'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: I ceased eating my meal.

section.para: Compare with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba di'i co'a bajra
interlinear-gloss.en: I will regularly begin to run.

section.para: which illustrates the combination of a TAhE with a ZAhO.

A process can have two end points, one reflecting the natural end(when the process is complete) and the other reflecting the
natural end actual stopping point(whether complete or not). may be contrasted with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu mo'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: I finished eating my meal.

section.para:
In , the meal has reached its natural end; in
natural end , the meal has merely ceased, without necessarily reaching its natural end.

A process such as eating a meal does not necessarily proceed uninterrupted. If it is interrupted, there are two more relevant point events: the point just before the interruption, marked by de'a, and the point just after the interruption, marked by
de'a di'a. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu de'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: I stopped eating my meal (with the intention of resuming).
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba di'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.en: I will resume eating my meal.

section.para:
In addition, it is possible for a process to continue beyond its natural end. The span of time between the natural and the actual end points is represented by
natural end za'o:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ctuca pu za'o ciksi le cmaci seldanfu le tadgri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The teacher [past] [superfective] explained the mathematics problem to the student-group.
interlinear-gloss.en: The teacher kept on explaining the mathematics problem to the class too long.

section.para: That is, the teacher went on explaining after the class already understood the problem.
An entire event can be treated as a single moment using the cmavo co'i:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu co'i catra la djim
interlinear-gloss.en: John was at the point in time where he killed Jim.

section.para: Finally, since an activity is cyclical, an individual cycle can be referred to using a number followed by re'u, which is the other cmavo of selma'o ROI:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pare'u klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the store for the first time (within a vague interval).

section.para: Note the difference between:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pare'u paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [first time] [one time] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.en: For the first time, I go to the store once.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi paroi pare'u klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [one time] [first time] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.en: There is one occasion on which I go to the store for the first time.

section.title: 11. Space interval modifiers: FEhE
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

Like time intervals, space intervals can also be continuous, discontinuous, or repetitive. Rather than having a whole separate set of selma'o for space interval properties, we instead prefix the flag
interval properties
continuous fe'eto the cmavo used for time interval properties. A space interval property would be placed just after the space interval size and/or dimensionality cmavo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ko vi'i fe'e di'i sombo le gurni
interlinear-gloss.en: Sow the grain in a line and evenly!
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi fe'e ciroi tervecnu lo selsalta
interlinear-gloss.en: I buy salad ingredients in three locations.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ze'e roroi ve'e fe'e roroi ku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: li re su'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.en: Always and everywhere, two plus two is four.

section.para: As shown in , when a tense comes first in a bridi, rather than in its normal position before the selbri (in this case du), it is emphasized.

The fe'emarker can also be used for the same purpose before members of ZAhO. (The cmavo be'abelongs to selma'o FAhA; it is the space direction meaning
be'a north of.)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: tu ve'abe'a fe'e co'a rokci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is the beginning of a rock extending to my north.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is the south face of a rock.

section.para:
Here the notion of a beginning pointrepresented by the cmavo
beginning point co'ais transferred from beginning in timeto beginning in spaceunder the influence of the fe'eflag. Space is not inherently oriented, unlike time, which flows from past to future: therefore, some indication of orientation is necessary, and the ve'abe'aprovides an orientation in which the south face is the
south face beginningand the north face is the end, since the rock extends from south (near me) to north (away from me).

Many natural languages represent time by a space-based metaphor: in English, what is past is said to be behind us. In other languages, the metaphor is reversed. Here, Lojban is representing space (or space interval modifiers) by a time-based metaphor: the choice of a FAhA cmavo following a VEhA cmavo indicates which direction is mapped onto the future. (The choice of future rather than past is arbitrary, but convenient for English-speakers.)
If both a TAhE (or ROI) and a ZAhO are present as space interval modifiers, the fe'eflag must be prefixed to each.

section.title: 12. Tenses as sumti tcita
section.para: So far, we have seen tenses only just before the selbri, or (equivalently in meaning) floating about the bridi with ku. There is another major use for tenses in Lojban: as sumti tcita, or argument tags. A tense may be used to add spatial or temporal information to a bridi as, in effect, an additional place:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ca le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [present] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market when you go to the house.

section.para: Here cadoes not appear before the selbri, nor with ku; instead, it governs the following sumti, the le nuconstruct. What asserts is that the action of the main bridi is happening at the same time as the event mentioned by that sumti. So ca, which means nowwhen used with a selbri, means simultaneously-withwhen used with a sumti. Consider another example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu le nu do pu klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: I go-to the market [past] the event-of you [past] go-to the house.

section.para: The second puis simply the past tense marker for the event of your going to the house, and says that this event is in the speaker's past. How are we to understand the first pu, the sumti tcita?

All of our imaginary journeys so far have started at the speaker's location in space and time. Now we are specifying an imaginary journey that starts at a different location, namely at the event of your going to the house. then says that my going to the market is in the past, relative not to the speaker's present moment, but instead relative to the moment when you went to the house. can therefore be translated:
section.programlisting: I had gone to the market before you went to the house.
section.para: (Other translations are possible, depending on the ever-present context.) Spatial direction and distance sumti tcita are exactly analogous:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [short distance] the park.
interlinear-gloss.en: The rat eats the cheese near the park.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le vu panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [short distance] the [long distance] park
interlinear-gloss.en: The rat eats the cheese near the faraway park.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vu le vi panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [long distance] the [short distance] park
interlinear-gloss.en: The rat eats the cheese far away from the nearby park.

section.para:
The event contours of selma'o ZAhO (and their space equivalents, prefixed with
tense direction event contours fe'e) are also useful as sumti tcita. The interpretation of ZAhO tcita differs from that of FAhA, VA, PU, and ZI tcita, however. The event described in the sumti is viewed as a process, and the action of the main bridi occurs at the phase of the process which the ZAhO specifies, or at least some part of that phase. The action of the main bridi itself is seen as a point event, so that there is no issue about which phase of the main bridi is intended. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [perfective] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.en: I die in the aftermath of my living.

section.para: Here the (point-)event of my being dead is the portion of my living-process which occurs after the process is complete. Contrast with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.en: I am-dead [future] the event-of I live.

section.para: As explained in , does not exclude the possibility that I died before I ceased to live!
Likewise, we might say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.en: I go-to the store [inchoative] the event-of I eat

section.para: which indicates that before my eating begins, I go to the store, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ba'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.en: I go-to the store [perfective] the event-of I eat

section.para: would indicate that I go to the store after I am finished eating.
Here is an example which mixes temporal ZAhO (as a tense) and spatial ZAhO (as a sumti tcita):

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le bloti pu za'o xelklama
interlinear-gloss.en: The boat sailed for too long and beyond the lake.

section.para: Probably it sailed up onto the dock. One point of clarification: although xelklamaappears to mean simply is-a-mode-of-transport, it does not - the bridi of has four omitted arguments, and thus has the (physical) journey which goes on too long as part of its meaning.

The remaining tense cmavo, which have to do with interval size, dimension, and continuousness (or lack thereof) are interpreted to let the sumti specify the particular interval over which the main bridi operates:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci reroi le ca djedi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [twice] the [present] day.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go/went/will go to the market twice today.

section.para: Be careful not to confuse a tense used as a sumti tcita with a tense used within a seltcita sumti:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: loi snime cu carvi ze'u le ca dunra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Some-of-the-mass-of snow rains [long time interval] the [present] winter.
interlinear-gloss.en: Snow falls during this winter.

section.para: claims that the interval specified by this winteris long, as events of snowfall go, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: loi snime cu carvi ca le ze'u dunra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Some-of-the-mass-of snow rains [present] the [long time] winter.
interlinear-gloss.en: Snow falls in the long winter.

section.para: claims that during some part of the winter, which is long as winters go, snow falls.

section.title: 13. Sticky and multiple tenses: KI
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

So far we have only considered tenses in isolated bridi. Lojban provides several ways for a tense to continue in effect over more than a single bridi. This property is known as stickiness: the tense gets stuckand remains in effect until explicitly unstuck. In the metaphor of the imaginary journey, the place and time set by a sticky tense may be thought of as a campsite or way-station: it provides a permanent origin with respect to which other tenses are understood. Later imaginary journeys start from that point rather than from the speaker.
To make a tense sticky, suffix kito it:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puki klama le zarci .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [sticky] go-to the market. The man bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market. The man bit the dog.

section.para: Here the use of pukirather than just puensures that the tense will affect the next sentence as well. Otherwise, since the second sentence is tenseless, there would be no way of determining its tense; the event of the second sentence might happen before, after, or simultaneously with that of the first sentence.
(The last statement does not apply when the two sentences form part of a narrative. See for an explanation of story time, which employs a different set of conventions.)
What if the second sentence has a tense anyway?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puki klama le zarci .i le nanmu pu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: I [past] [sticky] go-to the market. The man [past] bites the dog.

section.para: Here the second pudoes not replace the sticky tense, but adds to it, in the sense that the starting point of its imaginary journey is taken to be the previously set sticky time. So the translation of is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: I went to the market. The man had earlier bitten the dog.

section.para: and it is equivalent in meaning (when considered in isolation from any other sentences) to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci .i le nanmu pupu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: I [past] go-to the market. The man [past] [past] bites the dog.

section.para: The point has not been discussed so far, but it is perfectly grammatical to have more than one tense construct in a sentence:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puku mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: Earlier, I was going to go to the market.

section.para: Here there are two tenses in the same bridi, the first floating free and specified by puku, the second in the usual place and specified by ba. They are considered cumulative in the same way as the two tenses in separate sentences of . is therefore equivalent in meaning, except for emphasis, to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I was going to go to the market.

section.para: Compare and , which have a different meaning from and :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba klama le zarci puku
interlinear-gloss.en: I will have gone to the market earlier.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bapu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I will have gone to the market.

section.para: So when multiple tense constructs in a single bridi are involved, order counts - the tenses cannot be shifted around as freely as if there were only one tense to worry about.

But why bother to allow multiple tense constructs at all? They specify separate portions of the imaginary journey, and can be useful in order to make part of a tense sticky. Consider , which adds a second bridi and a kito :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pukiku mi ba klama le zarci .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: [past] [sticky] I [future] go-to the market. The man bites the dog.

section.para: What is the implied tense of the second sentence? Not puba, but only pu, since only puwas made sticky with ki. So the translation is:
section.programlisting: I was going to go to the market. The man bit the dog.
section.para: Lojban has several ways of embedding a bridi within another bridi: descriptions, abstractors, relative clauses. (Technically, descriptions contain selbri rather than bridi.) Any of the selbri of these subordinate bridi may have tenses attached. These tenses are interpreted relative to the tense of the main bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le ba'o zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the former market.

section.para:
The significance of the ba'oin is that the speaker's destination is described as being in the aftermath of being a market; that is, it is a market no longer. In particular, the time at which it was no longer a market is in the speaker's past, because the
in the aftermath ba'ois interpreted relative to the putense of the main bridi.
Here is an example involving an abstraction bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ca jinvi le du'u mi ba morsi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I now opine the fact-that I will-be dead.
interlinear-gloss.en: I now believe that I will be dead.

section.para: Here the event of being dead is said to be in the future with respect to the opinion, which is in the present.
kimay also be used as a tense by itself. This cancels all stickiness and returns the bridi and all following bridi to the speaker's location in both space and time.

In complex descriptions, multiple tenses may be saved and then used by adding a subscript to
multiple tenses ki. A time made sticky with kixipa(ki-sub-1) can be returned to by specifying kixipaas a tense by itself. In the case of written expression, the writer's here-and-now is often different from the reader's, and a pair of subscripted kitenses could be used to distinguish the two.

section.title: 14. Story time
section.para: Making strict use of the conventions explained in would be intolerably awkward when a story is being told. The time at which a story is told by the narrator is usually unimportant to the story. What matters is the flow of time within the story itself. The term storyin this section refers to any series of statements related in more-or-less time-sequential order, not just a fictional one.

Lojban speakers use a different set of conventions, commonly called story time, for inferring tense within a story. It is presumed that the event described by each sentence takes place some time more or less after the previous ones. Therefore, tenseless sentences are implicitly tensed as
story time what happens next. In particular, any sticky time setting is advanced by each sentence.
The following mini-story illustrates the important features of story time. A sentence-by-sentence explication follows:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puzuki ku ne'iki le kevna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: le ninmu goi ko'a zutse le rokci
the woman defined-as she-1 sat-on the rock
interlinear-gloss.en: Long ago, in a cave, a woman sat on a rock.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'a citka loi kanba rectu
interlinear-gloss.en: She was eating goat's meat.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'a pu jukpa ri le mudyfagri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: She [past] cook the-last-mentioned by-method the wood-fire.
interlinear-gloss.en: She had cooked the meat over a wood fire.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i lei rectu cu zanglare
interlinear-gloss.en: The meat was pleasantly warm.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i le labno goi ko'e bazaki nenri klama le kevna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The wolf defined-as it-2 [future] [medium] [sticky] within-came to-the cave.
interlinear-gloss.en: A while later, a wolf came into the cave.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'e lebna lei rectu ko'a
interlinear-gloss.en: It took the meat from her.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'e bartu klama
interlinear-gloss.en: It ran out.

section.para:
sets both the time (long ago) and the place (in a cave) using
cave ki, just like the sentence sequences in . No further space cmavo are used in the rest of the story, so the place is assumed to remain unchanged. The English translation of is marked for past tense also, as the conventions of English storytelling require: consequently, all other English translation sentences are also in the past tense. (We don't notice how strange this is; even stories about the future are written in past tense!) This conventional use of past tense is not used in Lojban narratives.

is tenseless. Outside story time, it would be assumed that its event happens simultaneously with that of
story time , since a sticky tense is in effect; the rules of story time, however, imply that the event occurs afterwards, and that the story time has advanced (changing the sticky time set in
story time ).
has an explicit tense. This is taken relative to the latest setting of the sticky time; therefore, the event of happens before that of . It cannot be determined if happens before or after .
is again tenseless. Story time was not changed by the flashback in , so happens after .
and are again tenseless, and so happen after . (Story time is changed.)
So the overall order is 14.1 - 14.3 - 14.2 - 14.4 - (medium interval) - 14.5 - 14.6 - 14.7. It is also possible that 14.3 happens before 14.1.

If no sticky time (or space) is set initially, the story is set at an unspecified time (or space): the effect is like that of choosing an arbitrary reference point and making it sticky. This style is common in stories that are jokes. The same convention may be used if the context specifies the sticky time sufficiently.

section.title: 15. Tenses in subordinate bridi
section.para: English has a set of rules, formally known as sequence of tense rules, for determining what tense should be used in a subordinate clause, depending on the tense used in the main sentence. Here are some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: John says that George is going to the market.
John says that George went to the market.
John said that George went to the market.
John said that George had gone to the market.

section.para: In and , the tense of the main sentence is the present: says. If George goes when John speaks, we get the present tense is going( goeswould be unidiomatic); if George goes before John speaks, we get the past tense went. But if the tense of the main sentence is the past, with said, then the tense required in the subordinate clause is different. If George goes when John speaks, we get the past tense went; if George goes before John speaks, we get the past-perfect tense had gone.

Lojban, like Russian and Esperanto, uses a different convention. A tense in a subordinate bridi is understood to be relative to the tense already set in the main bridi. Thus through can be expressed in Lojban respectively thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ca cusku le se du'u la djordj. ca klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: John [present] says the statement-that George [present] goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ca cusku le se du'u la djordj. pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: John [present] says the statement-that George [past] goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la djordj. ca klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: John [past] says the statement-that George [present] goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la djordj. pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: John [past] says the statement-that George [past] goes-to the market.

section.para:
Probably the most counterintuitive of the Lojban examples is . The calooks quite odd, as if George were going to the market right now, rather than back when John spoke. But this cais really a cawith respect to a reference point specified by the outer pu. This behavior is the same as the additive behavior of multiple tenses in the same bridi, as explained in
multiple tenses .

There is a special cmavo nau(of selma'o CUhE) which can be used to override these rules and get to the speaker's current reference point. (Yes, it sounds like English
nau now.) It is not grammatical to combine nauwith any other cmavo in a tense, except by way of a logical or non-logical connection (see
non-logical connection
nau ). Here is a convoluted sentence with several nested bridi which uses nauat the lowest level:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la .alis pu cusku le se du'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: la djordj. pu cusku le se du'u la maris. nau klama le zarci
John [past] says the statement-that Alice [past] says the statement-that
George [past] says the statement that Mary [now] goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: John said that Alice had said that George had earlier said that Mary is now going to the market.

section.para: The use of naudoes not affect sticky tenses.

section.title: 16. Tense relations between sentences
section.para: The sumti tcita method, explained in , of asserting a tense relationship between two events suffers from asymmetry. Specifically,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba cu cadzu le bisli zu'a le nu le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child walks-on the ice [left] the event-of the man bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walks on the ice to the left of where the man bites the dog.

section.para: which specifies an imaginary journey leftward from the man biting the dog to the child walking on the ice, claims only that the child walks on the ice. By the nature of le nu, the man's biting the dog is merely referred to without being claimed. If it seems desirable to claim both, each event can be expressed as a main sentence bridi, with a special form of .iconnecting them:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .izu'abo le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bites the dog. To the left, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: .izu'abois a compound cmavo: the .iseparates the sentences and the zu'ais the tense. The bois required to prevent the zu'afrom gobbling up the following sumti, namely le verba.

Note that the bridi in appear in the reverse order from their appearance in . With .izu'abo(and all other afterthought tense connectives) the sentence specifying the origin of the journey comes first. This is a natural order for sentences, but requires some care when converting between this form and the sumti tcita form.
means the same thing as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: .i zu'a la'edi'u le verba cu cadzu le bisli
[Left] the-referent-of-the-last-sentence the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bites the dog. Left of what I just mentioned, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: If the bois omitted in , the meaning changes:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'a le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child [something] walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bites the dog. To the left of the child, something walks on the ice.

section.para: Here the first place of the second sentence is unspecified, because zu'ahas absorbed the sumti le verba.
Do not confuse either or with the following:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'aku le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bites the dog. Left of me, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: In , the origin point is the speaker, as is usual with zu'aku. makes the origin point of the tense the event described by the first sentence.

Two sentences may also be connected in forethought by a tense relationship. Just like afterthought tense connection, forethought tense connection claims both sentences, and in addition claims that the time or space relationship specified by the tense holds between the events the two sentences describe.
The origin sentence is placed first, preceded by a tense plus gi. Another giis used to separate the sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pugi mi klama le zarci gi mi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] I go-to the market [,] I go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.en: Before I go to the market, I go to the house.

section.para: A parallel construction can be used to express a tense relationship between sumti:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama pugi le zarci gi le zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: I go-to [past] the market [,] the house.

section.para:
Because English does not have any direct way of expressing a tense-like relationship between nouns,
nouns cannot be expressed in English without paraphrasing it either into or else into I go to the house before the market, which is ambiguous - is the market going?

Finally, a third forethought construction expresses a tense relationship between bridi-tails rather than whole bridi. (The construct known as a bridi-tailis explained fully in ; roughly speaking, it is a selbri, possibly with following sumti.) is equivalent in meaning to and :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pugi klama le zarci gi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market [,] go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.en: I, before going to the market, go to the house.

section.para: In both and , the underlying sentences mi klama le zarciand mi klama le zdaniare not claimed; only the relationship in time between them is claimed.

Both the forethought and the afterthought forms are appropriate with PU, ZI, FAhA, VA, and ZAhO tenses. In all cases, the equivalent forms are (where X and Y stand for sentences, and TENSE for a tense cmavo):
section.programlisting: subordinate: X TENSE le nu Y afterthought coordinate: Y .i+TENSE+bo X forethought coordinate: TENSE+gi X gi Y

section.title: 17. Tensed logical connectives
section.para:
The Lojban tense system interacts with the Lojban logical connective system. That system is a separate topic, explained in
tense system and touched on only in summary here. By the rules of the logical connective system, through 17.3 are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ije la teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat. And Terry strokes the rabbit.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu gi'e satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat and strokes the rabbit.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .e le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat and the rabbit.

section.para: Suppose we wish to add a tense relationship to the logical connective and? To say that Terry strokes the cat and later strokes the rabbit, we can combine a logical connective with a tense connective by placing the logical connective first, then the tense, and then the cmavo bo, thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ijebabo la teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat. And then Terry strokes the rabbit.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu gi'ebabo satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat, and then strokes the rabbit.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ebabo le ractu
interlinear-gloss.en: Terry strokes the cat and then the rabbit.

section.para: through 17.6 are equivalent in meaning. They are also analogous to through respectively. The bois required for the same reason as in : to prevent the bafrom functioning as a sumti tcita for the following sumti (or, in , from being attached to the following selbri).

In addition to the boconstruction of through , there is also a form of tensed logical connective with
tensed logical connective
tensed logical connective tensed logical connective
tensed logical connective ke ... ke'e( tu'e ... tu'ufor sentences). The logical connective system makes through equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije tu'e mi bevri le gerku .ija mi bevri le mlatu tu'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And (I carry the dog. And/or I carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.en: I carry the sack. And I carry the dog, or I carry the cat, or I carry both.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'eke bevri le gerku gi'a bevri le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (carry the dog and/or carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.en: I carry the sack, and also carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .eke le gerku .a le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (the dog or the cat).
interlinear-gloss.en: I carry the sack and also the dog or the cat or both.

section.para: Note the uniformity of the Lojban, as contrasted with the variety of ways in which the English provides for the correct grouping. In all cases, the meaning is that I carry the sack in any case, and either the cat or the dog or both.
To express that I carry the sack first (earlier in time), and then the dog or the cat or both simultaneously, I can insert tenses to form through :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije ba tu'e mi bevri le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And [future] (I carry the dog.
I carry the sack. And then I will carry the dog or I will carry the cat
interlinear-gloss.en: or I will carry both at once.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'ebake bevri le gerku gi'acabo bevri le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (carry the dog and/or [present] carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.en: I carry the sack and then will carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both at once.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ebake le gerku .acabo le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (the cat and/or [present] the dog).
interlinear-gloss.en: I carry the sack, and then the cat or the dog or both at once.

section.para: through are equivalent in meaning to each other, and correspond to the tenseless through respectively.

section.title: 18. Tense negation
section.para: Any bridi which involves tenses of selma'o PU, FAhA, or ZAhO can be contradicted by a -naisuffixed to the tense cmavo. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi punai klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I didn't go to the market.

section.para: As a contradictory negation, implies that the bridi as a whole is false without saying anything about what is true. When the negated tense is a sumti tcita, -nainegation indicates that the stated relationship does not hold:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci canai le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [present] [not] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.en: It is not true that I went to the market at the same time that you went to the house.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu batci le gerku ne'inai le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog [within] [not] the room.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man didn't bite the dog inside the room.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ca'onai le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [continuitive - negated] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.en: It is false that I am dead during my life.

section.para: It is also possible to perform scalar negation of whole tense constructs by placing a member of NAhE before them. Unlike contradictory negation, scalar negation asserts a truth: that the bridi is true with some tense other than that specified. The following examples are scalar negation analogues of to :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market other than in the past.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu batci le gerku to'e ne'i le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog [opposite-of] [within] the room.
interlinear-gloss.en: The man bites the dog outside the room.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci na'e ca le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [non-] [present] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market at a time other than the time at which you went to the house.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi na'e ca'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [non-] [continuitive] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.en: I am dead other than during my life.

section.para: Unlike -naicontradictory negation, scalar negation of tenses is not limited to PU and FAhA:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba na'e ri'u cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.en: The child walks on the ice other than to my right.

section.para: The use of -naion cmavo of TAhE and ROI has already been discussed in ; this use is also a scalar negation.

section.title: 19. Actuality, potentiality, capability: CAhA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
Lojban bridi without tense markers may not necessarily refer to actual events: they may also refer to capabilities or potential events. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka cu flulimna
interlinear-gloss.en: All ducks swim by floating.

section.para: is a Lojban truth, even though the colloquial English translation is false or at best ambiguous. This is because the tenseless Lojban bridi doesn't necessarily claim that every duck is swimming or floating now or even at a specific time or place. Even if we add a tense marker to ,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ca flulimna
interlinear-gloss.en: All ducks are now swimming by floating.

section.para: the resulting might still be considered a truth, even though the colloquial English seems even more likely to be false. All ducks have the potential of swimming even if they are not exercising that potential at present. To get the full flavor of All ducks are now swimming, we must append a marker from selma'o CAhA to the tense, and say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ca ca'a flulimna
interlinear-gloss.en: All ducks are now actually swimming by floating.

section.para: A CAhA cmavo is always placed after any other tense cmavo, whether for time or for space. However, a CAhA cmavo comes before ki, so that a CAhA condition can be made sticky.
is false in both Lojban and English, since it claims that the swimming is an actual, present fact, true of every duck that exists, whereas in fact there is at least one duck that is not swimming now.

Furthermore, some ducks are dead (and therefore sink); some ducks have just hatched (and do not know how to swim yet), and some ducks have been eaten by predators (and have ceased to exist as separate objects at all). Nevertheless, all these ducks have the innate capability of swimming - it is part of the nature of duckhood. The cmavo
innate capability ka'eexpresses this notion of innate capability:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ka'e flulimna
interlinear-gloss.en: All ducks are innately capable of swimming.

section.para: Under some epistemologies, innate capability can be extended in order to apply the innate properties of a mass to which certain individuals belong to the individuals themselves, even if those individuals are themselves not capable of fulfilling the claim of the bridi. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ka'e viska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John is innately capable of seeing.
interlinear-gloss.en: John can see.

section.para: might be true about a human being named John, even though he has been blind since birth, because the ability to see is innately built into his nature as a human being. It is theoretically possible that conditions might occur that would enable John to see (a great medical discovery, for example). On the other hand,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le cukta ka'e viska
interlinear-gloss.en: The book can see.

section.para: is not true in most epistemologies, since the ability to see is not part of the innate nature of a book.

Consider once again the newly hatched ducks mentioned earlier. They have the potential of swimming, but have not yet demonstrated that potential. This may be expressed using nu'o, the cmavo of CAhA for undemonstrated potential:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro cifydatka nu'o flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All infant-ducks [can but has not] are-float-swimmers.
All infant ducks have an undemonstrated potential for swimming by floating.
interlinear-gloss.en: Baby ducks can swim but haven't yet.

section.para: Contrariwise, if Frank is not blind from birth, then pu'iis appropriate:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. pu'i viska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank has demonstrated a potential for seeing.
interlinear-gloss.en: Frank can see and has seen.

section.para:
Note that the glosses given at the beginning of this section for ca'a,
ca'a nu'o, and
nu'o pu'iincorporate
pu'i cainto their meaning, and are really correct for ca ca'a,
ca'a ca nu'o, and
nu'o ca pu'i. However, the CAhA cmavo are perfectly meaningful with other tenses than the present:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu ca'a klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I actually went to the store.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. ba nu'o klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank [future] [can but has not] goes-to the store.
Frank could have, but will not have, gone to the store
interlinear-gloss.en: (at some understood moment in the future).

section.para: As always in Lojban tenses, a missing CAhA can have an indeterminate meaning, or the context can be enough to disambiguate it. Saying

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta jelca
interlinear-gloss.en: That burns/is-burning/might-burn/will-burn.

section.para: with no CAhA specified can translate the two very different English sentences That is on fireand That is inflammable.The first demands immediate action (usually), whereas the second merely demands caution. The two cases can be disambiguated with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ca ca'a jelca
interlinear-gloss.en: That is on fire.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ka'e jelca
interlinear-gloss.en: That is inflammable.

section.para: When no indication is given, as in the simple observative

interlinear-gloss.jbo: jelca
interlinear-gloss.en: It burns!

section.para: the prudent Lojbanist will assume the meaning Fire!

section.title: 20. Logical and non-logical connections between tenses
section.para: Like many things in Lojban, tenses may be logically connected; logical connection is explained in more detail in . Some of the terminology in this section will be clear only if you already understand logical connectives.
The appropriate logical connectives belong to selma'o JA. A logical connective between tenses can always be expanded to one between sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I went and will go to the market.

section.para: means the same as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci .ije mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market. And I [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market, and I will go to the market.

section.para: Tense connection and tense negation are combined in:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi punai je canai je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [not] and [present] [not] and [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I haven't yet gone to the market, but I will in future.

section.para: is far more specific than

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: I [future] go-to the market.

section.para: which only says that I will go, without claiming anything about my past or present. badoes not imply punaior canai; to compel that interpretation, either a logical connection or a ZAhO is needed.
Tense negation can often be removed in favor of negation in the logical connective itself. The following examples are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi mo'izu'anai je mo'iri'u cadzu
interlinear-gloss.en: I walk not leftward but rightward.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi mo'izu'a naje mo'iri'u cadzu
interlinear-gloss.en: I walk not leftward but rightward.
